an6.34:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an6.34:1.2: Then as Venerable Mahāmoggallāna was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,
an6.34:1.4: stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening?”
an6.34:1.5: Now, at that time a monk named Tissa had recently passed away and been reborn in a realm of divinity.
an6.34:1.7: The divinity Tissa was very mighty and powerful.
an6.34:2.1: And then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from Jeta’s Grove and reappeared in that realm of divinity.
an6.34:2.2: Tissa saw Moggallāna coming off in the distance,
an6.34:2.4: “Come, my good Moggallāna! Welcome, my good Moggallāna!
an6.34:2.5: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.
an6.34:2.6: Sit, my good Moggallāna, this seat is for you.”
an6.34:2.7: Moggallāna sat down on the seat spread out.
an6.34:2.8: Then Tissa bowed to Moggallāna and sat to one side.
an6.34:3.1: “Tissa, which gods know that they are stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening?”
an6.34:3.2: “The gods of the four great kings know this.”
an6.34:4.1: “But do all of them know this?”
an6.34:4.2: “No, my good Moggallāna, not all of them.
an6.34:4.3: Those who lack experiential confidence in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and lack the ethics loved by the noble ones, do not know that they are stream-enterers.
an6.34:4.4: But those who have experiential confidence in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and have the ethics loved by the noble ones, do know that they are stream-enterers.”
an6.34:5.1: “But Tissa, is it only the gods of the four great kings who know that they are stream-enterers, or do the gods of the thirty-three …
an6.34:5.4: the gods who love to create …
an6.34:5.5: and the gods who control what is created by others know that they are stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening?”
an6.34:5.6: “The gods of these various classes know this.”
an6.34:6.1: “But do all of them know this?”
an6.34:6.2: “No, my good Moggallāna, not all of them.
an6.34:6.3: Those who lack experiential confidence in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and lack the ethics loved by the noble ones, do not know that they are stream-enterers.
an6.34:6.4: But those who have experiential confidence in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and have the ethics loved by the noble ones, do know that they are stream-enterers.”
an6.34:7.1: Moggallāna approved and agreed with what the divinity Tissa said. Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from that realm of divinity and reappeared in Jeta’s Grove.
